frameDefinitions: A Communicator or Medium assigns linguistic meaning to an Unresolved_referent thereby identifying the specific actor or entity which fulfills the answer to this question.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer adding some Phenomenon to their model of the world.
These are words describing basic commercial transactions involving a buyer and a seller exchanging money and goods, taking the perspective of the seller.
A Communicator or Medium briefly references something in a Message, in which only a subpart of the full content is profiled.
An Entity is understood to be experienceable within a particular set of delimited Circumstances, which may be more narrowly expressed by a Time, Place.
This frame contains verbs and nouns that communicate the act of a Speaker to address a Message to some Addressee using language.
frameExamples: Can you <t>name</t> all the U.S. Presidents?
Later that night, they <t>found</t> the barely-alive victim inside the Red Hall estate flat.
Robin <t>sold</t> a car to Abby for $5,000.
The General Secretary <t>mentions</t> some of them in his report.
This type of behavior <t>occurs</t> in several primate mating rituals.
I now <t>declare</t> you members of this Society.
listRoleDefinitions: The person who uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey the <fen>Unresolved_referent</fen> to another person.
The thing to which the <fen>Communicator</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> refers for identification purposes.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Unresolved_referent</fen> is conveyed.
When the the <fen>Communicator</fen> is makes the indication.
The location where the <fen>Communicator</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> indicates the <fen>Unresolved_referent</fen>.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person who becomes aware of a <fen>Phenomenon</fen>. It is normally expressed as an External Argument.
Thm <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is the entity or situation in the world of which a <fen>Cognizer</fen> becomes aware. It is normally expressed as an Object:
This role identifes the <fen>Means</fen> by which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> becomes aware of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Topic</fen> indicates the general field within which the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is found.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> uses an <fen>Instrument</fen> to (enable themselves to) become aware of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.  In some cases, the <fen>Instrument</fen> may appear in subject position.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> becomes aware of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Buyer</fen> has the <fen>Money</fen> and wants the <fen>Goods</fen>.
The role <fen>Goods</fen> is anything (including labor or time, for example) which is exchanged for <fen>Money</fen> in a transaction.
The <fen>Seller</fen> has possession of the <fen>Goods</fen> and exchanges them for <fen>Money</fen> from a <fen>Buyer</fen>.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The person who uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to another person.
A proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The relevant entity or state-of-affairs that the <fen>Communicator</fen> mentions.
When the the <fen>Message</fen> is mentioned.
The location where the <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates the <fen>Message</fen>.
An object or event that is described as being available under delimited Conditions.
A temporal characterization of the circumstances of the existence of an <fen>Entity</fen>.
A spacial characterization of the <fex name=''>Circumstances</fex> of the existence of the <fex name=''>Entity</fex>.
A description of the state of the world in which the <fen>Entity</fen> can be experienced.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen> (whether spoken or written).  It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target	</t> word, or as the Genitive modifier of the noun.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.  It can be expressed as a clause or as a noun phrase.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to transmit the statement.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Message</fen> is made.
The role specifies the location where the <fen>Message</fen> takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>When this is resolved</fex>, I will name the winner.
<fex>Pat</fex> discovered a great little restaurant in Soho.
Pat discovered <fex>a great little restaurant</fex> in Soho.
<fex>By opening the book to page 10</fex>, you will find the Van Eerdens' number.
Scientists attempt to make discoveries <fex>about the laws of nature</fex>.
Olson says the deputy came out to the farm and detected a radioactive substance <fex>with his Geiger counter</fex>.
Robbie had wondered if they would be able to find the path <fex>at night</fex>.
So far, <fex>my company</fex> has sold more than three million copies.
A CBS report did mention <fex>that the First Lady was required to wear a flak jacket for her safety</fex>.
<fex>The report</fex> also mentioned contamination problems during the manufacture.
If someone mentions <fex>things like ration books</fex> , my stomach turns.
Evelyn said <fex>that she was not ready to leave</fex>.
Kim preached to me <fex>over the phone</fex>.
In some remarks <fex>at the National Press Club</fex>, Mr. Keating said he would make a better prime minister tha nMr. Hawke.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Upledger J. Your Inner Physician and You: CranioSacral Therapy
Your Inner Physician and You: CranioSacral Therapy and SomatoEmotional Release
as much as one-sixteenth of an inch
